meanings.definition: To confirm or substantiate the truth or accuracy of something.
meanings.sent1: She was validating the test results to make sure they were correct.
meanings.sent2: The scientist was validating her hypothesis through careful experimentation.
meanings.sent3: The detective was validating the suspect's alibi, but it turned out to be a clever lie.
meanings.sent4: Her success in the competition was validating all her hard work and dedication.
meanings.sent5: The judge's decision was validating the plaintiff's claim beyond any doubt.

meanings.definition: To make something officially acceptable or recognized.
meanings.sent1: The school was validating the students' diplomas after they completed all the required courses.
meanings.sent2: The government agency was validating the new software before approving its use in public offices.
meanings.sent3: The magician was validating his trick as the most amazing illusion ever performed.
meanings.sent4: Her smile was validating the importance of kindness in a world full of challenges.
meanings.sent5: The certificate was validating her expertise in the field, opening new career opportunities.

meanings.definition: To give official sanction or approval to something.
meanings.sent1: The committee was validating the decision to proceed with the construction project.
meanings.sent2: The city council was validating the new law to ensure it aligned with the constitution.
meanings.sent3: The chef was validating the recipe by adding a unique twist to the traditional dish.
meanings.sent4: His signature was validating the contract, sealing the deal between the two companies.
meanings.sent5: The royal decree was validating the noble title bestowed upon the brave knight.
